item.description:
This event is for all the word nerds in Nerd Fun! Author Joshua Kendall will discuss his biography of Noah Webster: The Forgotten Founding Father: Noah Webster's Obsession and the Creation of an American Culture.

My copy of Webster's Collegiate Dictionary looks surprisingly pristine despite heavy use, but that's only because I purchase a copy every time a new edition is published. If you love words and work with them every day as I do, you can't help but be curious about the man behind this indispensable reference.

This event is free. No tickets are required.

*****From the Harvard Book Store website (www.harvard.com/event/): In 1797, Noah Webster moved back to New Haven, Connecticut, with his family to begin his dictionary. Having made a fortune from his publishing ventures, Webster could afford to follow his heart. The first editon of his American Dictionary of the English Language was published in 1828. He would continue working on revisions until the day he died. This obsession . . . ended up giving America a language of its own.*****

I plan to be at the Harvard Bookstore between 6:15 and 6:30 p.m. Look for me in the bookstore: I'll be carrying a meetup sign or a red backpack, or both.

I won't be going out after this event, but I can meet at the Algiers Coffee House (40 Brattle Street, in Harvard Square) before the event. I plan to be there by 5:15 p.m., maybe earlier. If you plan to meet me there, be prepared to add 25% to the cost of your order for both the tax and the tip. Bring cash to make division of the check easier.

I'll be at the Algiers Coffee House between 5:15 and 6:15. I will be at the Harvard Book Store between 6:15 and 6:30.

The author discussion starts at 7:00 p.m.

Marianne
